race.name: Battenkill
race.tagline: New York rolling hills gravel in Cambridge.

climate.description: Variable spring conditions with cool temperatures and rain possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling eastern New York hills. Significant elevation with rural scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional NY event. Significant rolling hills but regional field.

biased_opinion.verdict: Eastern New York Rolling Hills Gravel
biased_opinion.summary: Battenkill is an eastern New York gravel race‚Äî60+ miles of rolling hills with significant climbing. The organization is solid, and the Northeast reputation is decent. However, it's a regional field with standard gravel terrain, keeping it in Tier 3. Cambridge provides moderate access. The 60+ miles and 5000 feet of climbing are the main challenges.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid 60+ mile gravel challenge with significant climbing. Worth it for the distance and elevation challenge. Not a destination race for terrain variety or field depth.

final_verdict.one_liner: New York rolling hills gravel with significant climbing.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you want a 60+ mile challenge with significant climbing‚Äîyes, it's a solid event. If you want terrain variety or pro field depth‚Äîlook elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Northeast events: Vermont Overland, D2R2. For similar distance events: other regional gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Cambridge has limited lodging. Saratoga Springs or Albany have more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.signature_challenge: 60+ miles with 5000 feet of rolling hills climbing.

non_negotiables.why: 5000 feet of rolling hills requires sustained climbing fitness.
NY spring means variable conditions and rain possible.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: New York rolling hills gravel with significant climbing.

logistics.explanation: Start near Cambridge Train Depot with police escort and neutral rollout shows proper organization. CJ Rudy noted extensive volunteer support: "Major intersections featured police officers or state troopers. The remaining roads had volunteers eagerly guiding riders." Three aid stations and sag support cover basics, though rural Cambridge requires advance lodging planning.

length.explanation: The 65-mile distance hits the sweet spot for spring classic suffering. Multiple options from 24-mile Piccolo to 75-mile Gran Fondo let riders choose their poison. As MDcatV discovered, "the relentless 6K feet of 1 to 3 minute climbs" make the distance feel much longer when the grades start stacking up in Washington County. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Mixed surfaces require bike handling skills, but Washington County gravel is generally smooth and hard-packed. The challenge comes from mud conditions rather than technical terrain. CJ Rudy found that on Juniper Swamp's 14% grade, you "stand up and risk losing traction or remain seated and feel the gravel reaching up and holding forward motion ransom." Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 5,500 feet of gain with climbs hitting 18% grade creates serious suffering through the Battenkill Valley. The course features "many rollers and several notably steep climbs on gravel" that build relentless fatigue. MDcatV emphasized the punishment: "the relentless 6K feet of 1 to 3 minute climbs" proved more decisive than the gravel sectors themselves.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 68¬∞F and lows of 46¬∞F, with a 47% chance of rain on any given day. Early May in upstate New York delivers unpredictable conditions. The 2025 race earned "flahute" status when CJ Rudy found "it had been raining all week" before race day. Spring weather swings from perfect to miserable - "it was cool enough to play havoc on attire" as rain stopped mid-race, creating dramatic temperature changes. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Cambridge, NY sits in rural Washington County at elevation that won't affect anyone's breathing. This is East Coast racing where altitude never factors into performance or acclimatization planning. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: You're riding the resurrected 'Queen of the Classics' through covered bridges and scenic hamlets in the Battenkill Valley. The primitive routes and potential for epic mud battles add adventure beyond just another gravel grind. It's not exotic, but there's real character in these Washington County back roads that money can't manufacture.

prestige.explanation: Originally the "largest sanctioned Pro/Am race in US history" from 2005-2017, earning "Queen of the Classics" status with riders from 48 states and 20 countries. The 2025 resurrection by Anthem Sports brought back the legend after seven-year dormancy. CJ Rudy confirmed the 2025 event "earned itself" the coveted "flahute" label reserved for extreme occasions.

race_quality.explanation: The course delivers serious suffering through Battenkill's trademark 12 dirt sections with proper race support. Organization includes extensive volunteer coverage and emergency presence. Despite 2025's brutal mud conditions, riders still found it "an absolute joy to complete" - the suffering comes from the terrain, not poor planning.

experience.explanation: Scenic villages and covered bridges provide stunning backdrop for punishment on primitive gravel roads. CJ Rudy noted the region is "simply cycling paradise" with "rolling hills that defy imagination." Even after consuming "only half of a water bottle and no nutrition" due to technical focus, riders emerge with rich stories from Washington County's challenging terrain.

community.explanation: The revival created a "one-of-a-kind race for those seeking a serious challenge shrouded in pastoral beauty" where everyone "goes home with rich stories to tell." After-party features "great food, entertainment, and libations" plus custom pint glasses. Anthem Sports maintains "grassroots cycling forever" philosophy while supporting local community fundraising.

field_depth.explanation: The pro/am format brings speed to the front, but field depth gets diluted across multiple distance options. FormerRower crashed hard early but still managed top 20 in Cat 2, suggesting competitive but not murderous depth. The race is rebuilding elite concentration after seven-year absence from the calendar. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As John S (globecanvas) puts it: "I'm 10 pounds too heavy (or 20 watts too weak) to compete in races that are decided by raw watts per kilogram..."

value.explanation: Package includes Battenkill tee, custom pint glass, SAG support, stocked aid stations, and police coverage at intersections. Gran fondo riders get free beer and meal voucher at the expo. Strambecco selected it as one of the best road/gravel events in New England/NY, delivering spring classic experience through cycling paradise terrain.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-120. Cambridge, NY offers reasonable lodging like The Wildflower Inn without destination resort pricing. Rural upstate location keeps costs manageable compared to trendy gravel destinations. The grassroots event philosophy means you're paying for racing history and challenging terrain rather than premium amenities or corporate polish. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Tour of the Battenkill 2015
videos.description:
2015 running of the Tour of the Battenkill in Greenwich, NY.
Cat 4 D Open (no age restriction)
videos.curation_reason: Best available race footage specifically from Battenkill, showing actual race conditions and course terrain.

videos.title: 5 Things I Learned From My First Gravel Race
videos.description:
Manon has fallen in love with gravel so recently decided to test her off-road skills in a local gravel race‚Ä¶ the British National Championships! Armed with two fantastic Kona bikes and boundless enthusiasm, she achieved a great result. Looking back, Manon takes you through the 5 lessons she has learned from her first gravel racing experience!

In partnership with Kona Bikes üëâ  https://gcn.eu/Kona

The Global Cycling Network (GCN) is the largest and fastest-growing online cycling channel in the world, bringing together a global community of road cyclists to celebrate everything that‚Äôs great about the world of cycling. 

Our videos bring fans compelling daily content including expert tutorials, techniques, training, racing, cutting-edge bike tech, unparalleled behind the scenes event coverage, humour,  entertainment, and more. 

Presented by ex-pro riders, GCN offers a uniquely qualified insight into the world of cycling, and most importantly it‚Äôs fuelled by our passionate and enthusiastic fans ‚Äì everyone who makes up the GCN community. We also bring you the latest and greatest tech to your attention, showcase the best places in the world to ride and get exclusive access to events and races.

videos.transcript:
not so long ago i took part in my first
ever gravel race and absolutely loved it
but after having some time to reflect i
have learned quite a few things and a
few tips that if i'd have known before
the race would have definitely helped me
so in this video i'm going to share them
with you let's go
[Music]
first up tires and tire pressure for
anybody doing their first gravel event i
would definitely recommend doing some
research into the course i was lucky
enough to be able to go down and ride
the course the day before so i had a
good idea of what kind of tires i was
going to need my race had a lot of
compact gravel and sand so i knew these
wider slicker tires were going to be
perfect for the job instead of the
narrower knobblier tires but if you
can't get to the course and ride it the
day before you can always look at all
pictures from the race or maybe a video
or take a quick look on maps or commute
next up tire pressure i went with 30 psi
for the race and not gonna lie that
sounds like absolutely nothing to me
coming from a track cycling background
where we pump our tires up to 200 psi
but i actually think i could have gone a
tiny bit less pressure because on the
grassier sections of the course it was
pretty bumpy and all those vibrations
going through my hands and my arms i
think i'm just a bit too soft so make
sure you do your research on the course
and make the right call on tire choice
because once the race starts you can't
change your tires or put more air in
them you probably take some air out but
that requires stopping and you don't
want to stop
next up is bike choice now the very kind
people at kona sent me two bikes to
choose from the rove and the libra some
of you guys that ride off-road might be
familiar with the kona as they are
pretty big in the mountain bike world
and know a thing or two about making
off-road bikes
it was quite a tough decision to choose
between these very beautiful gravel
bikes but it ultimately came down to the
handlebars so on the libra there are a
pretty wide set of handlebars which are
great for the technical sections of the
course there wasn't that many techie
bits on the course i was racing on so i
went for the rove which had a slightly
narrower handlebars which were great for
the fast terrain i was faced with the
rove also has flared handlebars
something you often see on gravel bikes
but i've never actually used the flared
bars before but i was very impressed it
gave a very relaxed feel when riding on
the faster fire roads
i did run slightly different
measurements on this bike than i
normally would on my road bike i came
higher with the handlebars and a shorter
stem this was because it's a lot more
comfortable position to be in when
spending a long time on the really bumpy
gravel sections where there's a lot of
vibrations going through your hands and
a lot of pressure and it's also a little
bit better for handling
i had big plans to be well field for
this race i took plenty of gels and food
in my back pocket
how much do they eat
yeah just just the one gel i was
constantly thinking in the race man you
need to eat you need to drink
but when you're hanging on to wheels
going over seriously bumpy terrain
and you've had you're going so hard in
the race you feel a little bit sick from
the effort the last thing i wanted to do
was eat
and yeah i seriously did pay for it in
the last lap of the race
i hadn't been training anywhere near
enough for this race so i knew i had to
be wildfield to do well and get round in
the race and it does sound easy oh just
you know in the race just have a gel or
have a bath but when you're hanging on
to the wheels your heart rate is sky
high
it's not so easy but it is something i'm
definitely going to practice for next
time i come to do a gravel race because
in my case the race was only 70
kilometers
god help me if the race was 170
kilometers and i wasn't filled i'd
probably still be out there
my gravel race was on laps of 23
kilometers but a lot of events can be
done from point to point now this hadn't
even crossed my mind but when i got to
the start most people had spares in
their back pockets or in a saddlebag
this is definitely something i'm going
to do next time because i don't want to
be that person stuck out there with a
puncture with no spares and have to do
the walker shame back to the race hq
that's all you need to take is some
basic spares a mini pump a tube and some
tyre levers it might cost you the win
having to stop but at least you'll get
to the finish
turns out gravel races they start pretty
rapidly and i probably wasn't as
prepared as i could have been i had a
little ride round beforehand i think it
was five ten minutes of riding around
listening the legs off but i would
definitely recommend doing a little bit
more than i did going out for 15 20
minutes doing some warm-up activation
efforts so you get to that start line
and you're prepared for a fast start and
give yourself the best possible chance
so they are some of the things i learned
from doing my first ever gravel race if
you're looking to enter your first
gravel race make sure to take those
things into consideration so you don't
make the same mistakes i did and if you
did enjoy this video make sure to give
it a big thumbs up
